headline.main: Consumers Lose if U.S. Presses 'Unfair Traders'

docs.snippet: LEAD: Tensions have increased in international trade and the commitment of governments to free-trade talks is facing its ''sternest test,'' the organization sponsoring the talks said today.

docs.snippet: LEAD: The United States came under sharp and virtually unanimous criticism today at the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade for its threat to impose trade sanctions on Japan, Brazil and India.

docs.snippet: LEAD: After less than two months on the job, S. Linn Williams, the Deputy United States Trade Representative and the person chiefly responsible for trade relations with Japan, has walked into a maelstrom.

docs.snippet: LEAD: A tugboat captain who answered the distress call of the tanker that spilled thick fuel oil into the Delaware River said the ship ran aground when she inexplicably dropped anchor a mile and a half from port.

docs.snippet: LEAD: Trade negotiators here are considering a compromise proposal aimed at ending the voluntary restraint agreements that many nations including the United States use to protect their industries against an unexpected surge in imports.

byline.original: By BURTON BOLLAG, Special to The New York Times

docs.snippet: LEAD: Uncle Sam has forced Japan to cry uncle once again on trade. Tokyo agreed Wednesday to allow more imports of mobile telephones. This should help pierce Japan's protectionist shield against foreign competition. But Washington extracted that...
docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: Uncle Sam has forced Japan to cry uncle once again on trade. Tokyo agreed Wednesday to allow more imports of mobile telephones. This should help pierce Japan's protectionist shield against foreign competition. But Washington extracted that concession only by threatening heavy tariffs on Japanese products.

headline.main: On Trade, Bullying Isn't the Answer

docs.snippet: LEAD: Dr. Arturo Morales Carrion, a Puerto Rican educator who was a high State Department official in the Kennedy Administration, died of cancer Wednesday at his home in San Juan, a spokesman for the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico said yesterday in...
docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: Dr. Arturo Morales Carrion, a Puerto Rican educator who was a high State Department official in the Kennedy Administration, died of cancer Wednesday at his home in San Juan, a spokesman for the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico said yesterday in Washington. He was 75 years old.
